title: Theatre and Performance in Context
description: Students experience, analyze, and interpret a range of works of theatre and performance. Close attention is paid to the original circumstances in which these works were produced, the ways in which they have reflected and influenced the communities that produced them, and their relevance to current performance practice and research.

title: Shakespeare 1
description: A study of the plays written before 1599-1600, excluding Julius Caesar.
requirementsDescription: Prereq: Level at least 3A. Antireq: DRAMA 386

title: Selected Seminars in Drama & Theatre Arts
description: Seminars in special areas of drama and theatre. [Note: Formerly DRAMA 491. This is a repeatable course, subject to different content; it may be completed a total of four times.]

title: Performance Studies
description: This workshop course in performance studies explores performance as a way of knowing. It investigates performance as artistic practice and as a means of understanding historical, social, and cultural practices, including drama/theatre texts, poetry, narratives, and texts of everyday life.

title: Project Management in the Arts
description: This course introduces students to principles of project management relevant in a broad range of contexts including theatre, dance, film, and digital media production. Students explore arts management concepts such as budgeting, communication, scheduling, leadership, problem-solving, and conflict resolution. Concepts are applied in case studies that accommodate individual student interests.

title: Introduction to Critical Design Practices
description: How does design help us think? This studio course introduces students to practice-based methods for generating knowledge. Topics may include prototyping, performance as research, material thinking, multi-modal representation, and experience design. Students will test and explore how we learn differently through creative practices.
